A problem for us is how to get the information necessary to estimate our carbon footprint.
We know very well within our own network of what tracks we use and what handling efforts we have so we can measure the carbon footprint within our own network.
But as soon as a consignment leaves our network and goes into the partner network, we don't know any longer what route the consignment takes.
So what?

What modes are used for the transport and on the other hand, we also see that there still is a problem from the regulation side that it's still not clear on on a national and on the European basis how you should estimate your carbon footprint.
We still wait on any regulations that tell us how we can estimate the carbon footprint, and as long as that's not clear I guess we're fooling ourselves.

If we say we can estimate our carbon footprint, or if we can calculate it the best we can do is make an estimated guess an educated guess on what our carbon footprint is, and that's it for the time being, and I think if you think about optimizing your carbon footprint, you first have to make sure that there is transparency and we're still fighting with the transparency, and I think we're still a long way.
Away from starting to improve our carbon footprint.

If you are in the airfreight business to overseas handlers and what we have seen and what was or is still the major.
A problem for us is how to get the information necessary to estimate our carbon footprint.
We know very well within our own network of what tracks we use and what handling efforts we have so we can measure the carbon footprint within our own network.

So what?

What modes are used for the transport and on the other hand, we also see that there still is a problem from the regulation side that it's still not clear on on a national and on the European basis how you should estimate your carbon footprint.
